users.biography:
A place to share my love of cinema 
filmprobeblog@gmail.com
Writer ‚Ä¢ Actor ‚Ä¢ Designer
last_five_captions:
Hi, I‚Äôm Lydia & I‚Äôm FilmProbe‚Ä¶ 

Now there‚Äôs over 50K of you, I wanted to properly introduce myself and tell you a little about me‚Ä¶ 

Thank you for following FilmProbe, making content centred about film and television is one of the most important things in my life. It keeps me creative and it makes me happy to know I can share my love of cinema with all of you. 

Here‚Äôs to an exciting future ahead for FilmProbe, I hope you‚Äôll join me on the journey! Thank you again for following, engaging, liking and being a cinema lover‚Ä¶ like me! 

Please be sure to follow along if you love cinema and want to see some unique posts which showcase all corners of movies, television and how cinema makes us feel. 

#intro #filmprobe #hello #thankyou #film #movies #cinephile

Mickey 17 (2025) | Film Probe Review 

I hate dying. Mickey 17 is the brand new feature from critically acclaimed filmmaker, Bong Joon-ho. Mickey 17 is a science fiction comedy that sees a disposable employee sent on a human expedition to colonise a new world. 

Robert Pattinson shines as the lead in this quirky, weird and wonderful piece of cinema. 

This is a doozy, I apologise in advance for the extent of my comments and review but I had a lot of thoughts after leaving the cinema and wanted to share them all with you! 

Thank you so much for reading, if you enjoyed this review please be sure to follow along for more film & tv content. Also, join Probe HQ for exclusive content, early access and insights! #mickey17 #robertpattinson #bongjoonho

Anora (2024) | Film Probe Review 

After Anora‚Äôs Academy Award sweep, I‚Äôve had a few messages asking for my review of the film and of course, I was more than happy to share! Anora is an unconventional romantic comedy which plenty of chaos and action thrown in. 

I couldn‚Äôt share my review without sharing a few of my thoughts on its Academy Award wins too so please scroll to the end to see my thoughts. Anora was a gripping, enticing film that i genuinely enjoyed from beginning to end. 

Thank you so much for reading, if you enjoyed this review please be sure to follow along for more film & tv content! Also, join Probe HQ for exclusive content and conversations! #anora #mikeymadison #academyaward #seanbaker

Anxiety Inducing Movies | by Film Probe 

Here is a list of films that personally made me anxious whilst watching, nail biting, tension building, unpredictable, unforgettable movies! 

Have you ever been watching a film and realised, I‚Äôm sweating? Why am I biting my nails? Well, that film succeeded in making you feel anxious, nervous and uncertain! Sometimes anxiety inducing films aren‚Äôt the best watch but sometimes it‚Äôs amazing when a film makes you feel such intense emotion! 

This film could have been really long but I‚Äôd love to make a part two, please comment your favourite anxiety inducing films! Thank you so much for reading, if you enjoyed this post please be sure to follow along and join Probe HQ for exclusive content and insights! #anxiety #filmlist #feelinganxious

97th Academy Awards | Winners by Film Probe 

Anora won 5 Oscars | Best Picture, Best Lead Actress, Best Director, Best Original Screenplay, Best Editing 

The Brutalist won 3 Oscars | Best Leading Actor, Best Cinematography, Best Original Score 

Conclave won 1 Oscar | Best Adapted Screenplay 

The Substance won 1 Oscar | Best Make up and Hairstyling 

I‚Äôm Still Here won 1 Oscar | Best International Feature 

Wicked won 2 Oscars | Best Costume Design, Best Production Design 

A Real Pain won 1 Oscar | Best Supporting Actor 

Dune Part 2 won 2 Oscars | Best Sound, Best Visual Effects 

Emilia Perez won 2 Oscars | Best Supporting Actress, Best Original Song 

Flow won 1 Oscar | Best Animated Feature 

Congratulations to all the nominees and winners of this years #Oscars #Academy #AcademyAwards #Winners

last_five_captions:
Falling in Love with Asian Cinema (again)

Come Here (2021), The Novelist Film (2022), How to Make Millions Before Grandma Dies (2024), Columbus (2017), Past Lives (2023), We Made a Beautiful Bouquet (2021), Perfect Days (2023), Falling in Love Like in Movies (2023), Blue Bayou (2021), Suzhou River (2000), Comrades Almost a Love Story (1996), Chungking Express (1994), Little Forest: Summer/Autumn (2015), Masaan (2015), Linda Linda Linda (2005).

#asiancinema

‚ÄúThere are two kinds of people in the world. People who swing and people who don‚Äôt.‚Äù

Swing Girls (2004), Shinobu Yaguchi

#asiancinema #japanesecinema

The secret to enjoying more films is to be unapologetic about the ones you love. Ask yourself: Did it feel familiar? Did it ignite a spirit within you? Did you actually feel something for the first time in two weeks?? For many reasons (and more), D√¨di checked every one of those boxes. 

D√¨di (2024), Sean Wang 

#asiancinema

Inspired by our friends at @mubi - guess the film. 

#asiancinema

When was the last time a stranger made you see the world differently?

During a routine pickup, an elderly Vietnamese cab driver is taken hostage by three recently escaped Orange County convicts.

@singjlee Sundance-winning debut The Accidental Getaway Driver opens in select cities February 28!

Link in bio to get your tickets! üéüÔ∏è

#theaccidentalgetawaydriver

users.biography:

‚ú® Stories & themes to inspire conversation

last_five_captions:
I don‚Äôt want your body, but I hate to think about you with somebody else‚Ä¶

Heartbreak is never just one thing‚Äîit‚Äôs love slipping through your fingers, the ache of seeing someone else fill the space you once held, and the bittersweet memory of what you had.

For anyone who‚Äôs been hurt, healed, or somewhere in between, these stories delve into the quiet devastation of moving on‚Äîthe pain of a love that wasn‚Äôt enough, the haunting what-ifs of a different ending, and the fragile hope that, someday, letting go might feel okay.

What films or TV shows would you add to this list?

#Heartbreak #MovieRecommendation #Love #The1975

Matthew MacFadyen is the perfect Mr. Darcy

In this unforgettable scene from Pride and Prejudice (2005), Mr. Darcy finally bares his heart to Elizabeth Bennet, delivering one of the most iconic love confessions in film history. Matthew MacFadyen‚Äôs vulnerable, heartfelt portrayal of Darcy‚Äôs struggle between pride and deep love captures the essence of Jane Austen‚Äôs timeless romance, making this moment truly captivating.

Directed by Joe Wright, Pride and Prejudice also stars Keira Knightley as the headstrong Elizabeth, alongside Rosamund Pike, Donald Sutherland, and Judi Dench. The film received numerous accolades and remains a beloved adaptation of Austen‚Äôs classic novel.

What‚Äôs the most romantic movie moment you‚Äôve seen?

#PrideAndPrejudice #MatthewMacFadyen #KeiraKnightley #JaneAusten #Love #MovieScenes

Sad Boy Cinema

This list explores cinema‚Äôs quietly broken men‚Äîthose lost in longing, numbness, and disillusionment.

These are the stories of young men grappling with their own thoughts, hiding behind substances, or searching for a spark in a world that feels unbearably heavy.

What films and tv shows would you add to this list?

#sadboy #sadboi #cinema #callmebyyourname

They call you crazy‚Ä¶ until it‚Äôs too late

Somewhere between a social nightmare and a psychological thriller, The Invitation (2015) thrives on tension so thick you can‚Äôt breathe. In this scene, Will (Logan Marshall-Green) finally says what we‚Äôve all been thinking: where the hell is Choi? His paranoia clashes with the unsettling calm of his hosts, making you question whether he‚Äôs losing it or if something truly sinister is at play. The slow burn, the forced smiles, the lingering glances ‚Äì this film knows exactly how to make your skin crawl before pulling the rug out from under you. It‚Äôs paranoia dialed up to eleven.

Directed by Karyn Kusama, The Invitation is a masterclass in psychological horror, turning a simple dinner party into a waking nightmare. As Will reconnects with his ex-wife Eden (Tammy Blanchard) and her eerily serene new friends, past grief and present danger blur into something deeply unsettling. Also starring Michiel Huisman and Emayatzy Corinealdi, this is the kind of film that lingers long after the credits roll ‚Äì because, really, how well do you trust the people around you?

What‚Äôs a film that nailed that creeping sense of dread?

#TheInvitation #PsychologicalThriller #Paranoa #KarynKusama #Tension #SheKnows #SlowBurn #Horror #HorrorMovies #MovieScenes #MovieQuotes

Some days, you just need to dance through it.

There‚Äôs something strangely freeing about watching Davis (Jake Gyllenhaal) move through the world like nothing matters ‚Äì because, to him, nothing really does anymore. In Demolition, grief doesn‚Äôt look like sobbing in the rain. It looks like breaking things, feeling nothing, and dancing through the streets of New York like you‚Äôre the only person alive. It‚Äôs a moment of chaos and clarity all at once, when you‚Äôre too numb to care, but too alive to stop moving. Maybe you‚Äôve felt that too.

Directed by Jean-Marc Vall√©e (Dallas Buyers Club, Big Little Lies), Demolition is a raw, darkly funny, and deeply human look at loss. Gyllenhaal delivers one of his most underrated performances, playing a man who, after losing his wife, doesn‚Äôt just break down, he takes everything apart. Also starring Naomi Watts, Chris Cooper, and Judah Lewis, the film explores how grief doesn‚Äôt follow rules, and sometimes, the only way to move forward is to tear everything down first.

What‚Äôs your favourite dance scene from a film or TV show?

#JakeGyllenhaal #DemolitionMovie #Dancing #Dance #JeanMarcVallee #Grief #MovieScenes #Doechii

last_five_captions: Sharing a few of my favourites as I enter the 1st episode of my very own season 23 ‚ú®üñºÔ∏èü§ç

My Top 10 Movies Of All-Time
-
Epilogue:

The top 100 list consists of 56 English language and 44 foreign language films. Thank you for everyone who supported with the list through the last 10 days and who took them as recommendations instead of stirring up problems related to the 'rankings'.

A total of 20 Indian films featured which is natural because I am very much familiar with Indian films, specially Tamil which is my mother tongue. It's about time they get the recognition they deserve around here.

But the way I compiled this list was in the perspective of a deaf person who watches all the films with subtitles irrespective of the region it is from or the language it is in. So I see all of them as equally deserving.

Apologies to all the films I may have forgotten or couldn't add to the list. Y'all will be remembered and recommended in the upcoming days through various posts.

Atleast I wasn't pretentious to please everyone. Couldn't have lived with that. I was brutally honest here. Also the rankings doesn't really matter, the films does. 

- E.

Christopher Nolan reinvents TIME with every film he makes, it could be a sci-fi, mystery, drama or war. Now I'm excited to see how he is going to cooperate time with a biography.
-
H/T: @filmdreams

Spotlight Ep. 3: Oscars '25

Highlighting some of my favorite wins and moments at this year's Academy Awards.

Flow
Adrien Brody 
No Other Land
Sean Baker

Which win was your favorite?

#cineoholic #oscars #academyawards #flow #adrienbrody #timotheechalamet #dunepart2 #nootherland #seanbaker #anora #mikeymadison #indie #cinema #movies #films #cinephile

Prescription Ep. 3: Films to watch as a family

Nothing brings people closer like a great movie night! These 4 films are more than just stories‚Äîthey‚Äôre moments to laugh, cry, and connect with your loved ones. Whether it‚Äôs sharing life lessons, celebrating family, or finding joy in the little things, these prescriptions are perfect for creating memories together.

In the end, family is everything. And no, I did not include Fast and Furious in this reel.

What's your favorite movie to watch with your family?

üìçJoin us from 18-27 June 2025 as we celebrate the very best of independent film. Link in bio to buy your passes now.

*Members price is ¬£99 for one week only.

Get ready for the 32nd Raindance Film Festival.

With over 90% of the in competition films made by first and second-time filmmakers, join us in basking in the radiance of summer with a programme of relevant, radical, and glorious premieres of must-see films at #Raindance2024.

It‚Äôs time to give film a chance. Link in bio for more details.

One year of Monster ü©µ

Still: Monster (2023) dir. Hirokazu Koreeda

#MonsterFilm
#CannesFilmFestival

DAY OF THE FIGHT, the Opening Night film from the 31st Raindance Film Festival, is now in UK cinemas ü•ä

On the day of his first fight since leaving prison, a once celebrated boxer takes a redemptive journey through his past and present.  Jack Huston‚Äôs directorial debut, stars Michael Pitt, winner of Best Performance at Raindance 2023, alongside a stellar cast including Ron Perlman, Jose Pesci and a cameo from Steve Buscemi. You won‚Äôt want to miss this.

#Raindance2023
#DayoftheFight

users.biography:
Your cinephile bestie!
Obsessed with movies & awards season 
üá¶üá∫ Brisbane, Australia 
üìº Letterboxd - Ashlee Pradella
üèÜ Awards Expert - Ashlee Pradella
last_five_captions:
What‚Äôs your most powerful in theatre movie experience?

Interpret this question any way you want. What moved you the most, or made you go HOLY SHIT, or gave you goosebumps etc etc. 
I‚Äôm still riding that Anora best picture high and thinking about Sean Bakers incredible speech, and how much the cinema experience means to me! Watching a film at home can be convenient and fun enough, but the cinema can be life changing and gives us a shared experience we can‚Äôt get anywhere else. 

A few of mine:
- My number 1 is easily The Ending of The Departed. I was SHOCKED they could even do that in a movie.
- Avengers Endgame (obviously) IYKYK
- Dune Part 2, if for nothing but the sandworm scene, I‚Äôve never experienced audio like that before, I could literally feel it vibrating my whole body. 
- The ending of La La Land (literally never emotionally recovered) 
- LOTR Return of the King when I was 14, I‚Äôve never cried so much in my life!!!

WAY TOO EARLY OSCAR PREDICTIONS 2026 

Straight off the batt I have to say this is meant to be FUN, and yes this is obviously way too early to make predictions. That being said, this should be seen as more of a preview of what‚Äôs to come this year and what might be in the Oscar conversation (mainly based off talent involved including actors and directors). It‚Äôs also possible some of these movies don‚Äôt actually come out this year, and with acting categories it‚Äôs almost impossible to know if they‚Äôll land in lead or supporting roles so I‚Äôve taken a punt based on info we know. I‚Äôve also not worried too much about an Oscar package at this point, and just included buzzy performances. 

A few predictions: 
- ‚ÄòWicked: For Good‚Äô will make Best Picture but not do as well with Oscar nominations this time around 
- ‚ÄòAvatar: Fire and Ash‚Äô will miss Best Picture
- Robert Pattinson gets his first Oscar nomination from either films ‚ÄòThe Drama‚Äô or ‚ÄòDie, My Love‚Äô 
- F1 has the potential to take the blockbuster spot in Best Picture. 
- We see horror embraced again at the Oscar‚Äôs through either Frankenstein movies coming out. 
- Superman only picks up a few techs 

Let me know your super early predictions/ hot takes for next years Oscar‚Äôs ‚ù§Ô∏è
Doesn‚Äôt stop me trying üôàüôà

This is probably my favourite Oscar speech of all time ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è although Kieran Culkin one this year really got to me!!! 

Ben and Matt forever!

My first video review so please give it some love üôàüôà
If you prefer a written review I‚Äôve got one over on Letterboxd ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è

users.biography:
with Maisie Williams üéô
The club for lovers and makers of film üé• @maisie_williams @hannahmwills89 @lowrir
last_five_captions: This film should‚Äôve been seen by more people! From our latest episode on the genre hopping film Polite Society. We need more films like this to get a better chance in the cinemas#nidamanzoor @politesocietymovie

Hi FFC friends 
It‚Äôs been a little while without an update hasn‚Äôt it! We‚Äôve all been casting and filming some very exciting film projects we hope to be bringing to a cinema near you soon! Though we are missing our weekly film chats‚Ä¶
For now, we want to shout out 3 of our favourite films we‚Äôve seen in the last couple of months. Two you can catch in cinemas now and one which has just come onto Mubi.

ON FALLING üì¶ a beautifully rich and quietly heartbreaking feature debut by Laura Carreira. This was Hannah and Lowri‚Äôs favourite from London Film Festival last year. In cinemas from this Friday. You can catch a Q&A and screening at Watershed in Bristol TODAY (Wednesday 5th) if you‚Äôre quick! 

THE LAST SHOWGIRL ‚ú® visually delicious and great casting. We love to see older women in leading roles. More please. Directed by Gia Coppola, in cinemas now 

GRAND THEFT HAMLET üéÆ A very entertaining exploration of how art and technology found one another during those weird lockdown months. Hilarious, especially watched when with friends. Directed by Sam Crane and Pinny Grylls and now available on Mubi 

What have you been watching lately?

We‚Äôre backkkkk and we‚Äôre meeting some @bafta film nominees ‚ù§Ô∏è As always every awards season, we‚Äôre FAR more interested in seeing the industry newcomers getting their flowers.

In this episode, which is turning into a bit of an annual tradition for us, we meet the five brilliant nominees of the Best British Short Film category for 2025:

ü•Ä @theos_perspective director of ‚ÄúThe Flowers Stand Silently, Witnessing‚Äù

üêÇ @j__wei and @finn_constantine for their film ‚ÄúMarion‚Äù

‚úÇÔ∏è @hoozeer.film and @franzbhm for their film ‚ÄúRock, Paper, Scissors‚Äù @rockpaperscissorsua 

ü•õ @_miranda_stern_ and @aogene for their documentary short ‚ÄúMilk‚Äù @shortfilmmilk 

ü™≤ @mattystfu and @karisam20 for ‚ÄúStomach Bug‚Äù @galaziaproductions 

We asked the filmmakers about their individual routes into filmmaking and how they found their collaborators. We chat about what it‚Äôs like working with small budgets and how, despite this, they were able to boost the production value to make these gorgeous films that you can watch for yourselves on BAFTA‚Äôs YouTube. (And find out who wins on Sunday 16 February 7pm on BBC One & iPlayer)

This episode is in collaboration with @bafta üé≠

last_five_captions:
Happy Friday, everyone! üéâ 

Let‚Äôs kick off the weekend with a classic Bob Fosse number, ‚ÄúRich Man‚Äôs Frug,‚Äù featuring Suzanne Charny as the lead! üíÉ‚ú® 

Movie üé•: Sweet Charity (1969)

Dancing my way into the weekend with Shirley Temple in STAND UP AND CHEER! (1934)¬†

Ft: James Dunn¬†
üé∂: Baby Take a Bow¬†

This was Temple‚Äôs first ever part in a major feature film, even though she was only five-years-old. Her charm was evident to Fox executives, and she was ushered into corporate offices almost immediately after finishing this scene to extend her contract with the studio. This film catapulted her career into stardom.
Elvis Presley singing ‚ÄúBossa Nova Baby‚Äù in FUN IN ACAPULCO (1963).

Gordon MacRae sings ‚ÄòOh, What a Beautiful Mornin‚Äô‚Äô in Oklahoma! (1955). ‚òÄÔ∏è 

I hope everyone has a fabulous week!

The Ronettes bring the energy with their electrifying performance of ‚ÄúShout‚Äù in The Big T.N.T. Show (1965), a filmed concert featuring some of the biggest stars of the ‚Äò60s! 
Some of those included: 
	‚Ä¢	Ray Charles
	‚Ä¢	The Byrds
	‚Ä¢	Ike & Tina Turner
	‚Ä¢	Bo Diddley
	‚Ä¢	Donovan
	‚Ä¢	The Lovin‚Äô Spoonful
	‚Ä¢	Joan Baez

	‚Ä¢	Roger Miller

users.biography: There is Still Magic in the Movies
last_five_captions:
It‚Äôs that time of year once again! It‚Äôs time for Oscars! Oscar! Oscars! A night when movie lovers all around the world come together to celebrate the magic of cinema. Ever since I was young, Oscar Sunday has been a special day for me. The excitement I felt was second only to Christmas morning. I‚Äôd wake up early, before my siblings, gather my favorite snacks from the kitchen, and claim my spot on the couch. This was my day, and I wasn‚Äôt moving. The remote was mine.

I watched any program that featured the Oscars from the pre-shows on E!, the red carpet event and then finally the big show. Billy Crystal was my favorite host and made the whole event feel magical. In 1996 I vividly remember getting chills every time Braveheart won an award, and the theme music played as the honoree walked up to the stage. That feeling was burned deep into my psyche and my love for the Oscars has never left.

This year instead of posting who I think will win and who should win, I am just predicting who I want to win. I‚Äôm not trying to get the most right. I didn‚Äôt look up the Vegas betting odds, or read any industry predictions on who the winners might be, I‚Äôm purely basing my choice on who I believe should win the award‚Ä¶ based on my own criteria. It just feels more honest. If someone I predicted to win, does just that, know I am at home cheering, not because I was right but because I truly believed the deserved it.

Let me know who you would like to win the Oscar this year. For Best Actor do you think it should be Timothee Chalamet or Adrien Brody? There are no right or wrong answers and whoever wins deserves the award. But I love to know people‚Äôs reasonings. It gives me insight into their feelings on the movies. I love it. I hope it‚Äôs a great show this year and am excited to see what Conan O‚ÄôBrien will bring to the ceremony. They still haven‚Äôt found the charm that Billy Crystal was able to bring‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm hoping this Oscars Sunday we do. I want the night to feel special again, magical, have that sense of glamour and awe. I want Hollywood to shine like a polished Oscar statue. Who knows, it‚Äôs Oscars Sunday‚Ä¶ anything can happen!
I will be posting my predictions later this evening.

Finally we have a trailer and a release date for Gareth Evans ‚ÄúHavoc‚Äù starring Tom Hardy. The film wrapped production back in 2021, then reshoots began nearly 3 years later in July of 2024. It has been a long road to get this movie released. Evans who is best known for directing both ‚ÄúRaid‚Äù films, as well as 2018‚Äôs ‚ÄúApostle‚Äù and the 2020 series ‚ÄúGangs of London‚Äù brings us his new film which stars Tom Hardy, Forest Whitaker, Timothy Olyphant and Luis Guzman. The official synopsis for the film is- 

‚ÄúAfter a drug deal goes wrong, a detective must fight his way through the criminal underworld to rescue a politician‚Äôs estranged son, while untangling his city‚Äôs dark web of conspiracy and corruption.‚Äù 

I have attached the trailer to the link in my bio. This film is expected to release April 25, 2025 only on Netflix. This one looks wild and has been at the top of my Most Anticipated Llist since 2022. From the trailer the wait looks to be worth it! Enjoy
